turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Okay, I'm so frustrated with trying to write this resume. I've been staring at a blank page for hours. I need help making it sound… impressive. Can you help me write a resume to apply for software engineering positions?

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: I understand your frustration. Resume writing can be challenging. I can definitely assist you. To start, could you tell me about your work experience, skills, and any projects you've worked on? The more detail you provide, the better I can tailor your resume.

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Alright, let's see... I worked as a Junior Developer at Acme Corp for two years, mainly using Python and Django. Before that, I had a six-month internship at Beta Industries, focusing on front-end development with React. And I've got a bunch of personal projects on GitHub, like a to-do list app and a basic e-commerce site. Oh, and I'm proficient in Java as well. What's the best way to phrase all of that in a way that sounds good?

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: Okay, great! How about this for your work experience at Acme Corp: "Junior Developer at Acme Corp. Leveraged Python and Django to develop and maintain key features of [mention specific product or application], resulting in [quantifiable achievement, e.g., a 15% increase in user engagement]." For Beta Industries: "Front-End Development Intern at Beta Industries. Contributed to the development of user interfaces using React, gaining experience in [mention specific technologies or methodologies, e.g., component-based architecture]." For your personal projects, list them on your resume with a brief description and a link to your GitHub repository. This allows recruiters to easily view your work. Should I list Java as a skill or something else?

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: That's...better, I guess. But how do I make sure my resume gets past those automated screening systems? I've heard they just scan for keywords, so how do I know which keywords to even include? It seems kind of pointless if it's just going to be rejected by a bot.
